An appeal to any type of emotion is not by itself fallacious, but becomes fallacious when combined with a faulty premise.

source_article: If you choose not to administer triple antibiotic coverage for this patient with severe and extensive burns, you will be held responsible for any infectious complications that might eventually arise.
explanations: In this example, the use of triple antibiotic coverage might be considered to be a valid choice. Nevertheless, fear of possible complications and – particularly – of the risk of being held accountable for those complications, rway clearance adaptations should not form the rational basis of acceptance of our choice.

source_article: "Every person is either my enemy or my friend. If are my enemy I should hate them. If they are my friend I should love them So I should either love them or hate them."
explanations: Presenting a limited set of alternatives when there are others that are worth considering in the context. Obviously, the conclusion is too extreme because most people are neither your enemy nor your friend. (Note from Jad: I changed the pronouns to be more generic"

source_article: “Caldwell Hall is in bad shape. Either we tear it down and put up a new building, or we continue to risk students’ safety. Obviously we shouldn’t risk anyone’s safety, so we must tear the building down.”
explanations: The argument neglects to mention the possibility that we might repair the building or find some way to protect students from the risks in question—for example, if only a few rooms are in bad shape, perhaps we shouldn’t hold classes in those rooms.

source_article: If you aren’t a capitalist, you must be a communist.
explanations: Also sometimes referred to as a “false dichotomy,” this is a fallacy in which one incorrectly places limitations on one’s possible options in a given scenario. This fallacy rests on the false premise that one is faced with a binary choice when it’s possible that multiple options are available. In essence, this occurs when one reduces the array of available options and alternatives to a simplified either-or condition.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I’m against the war.
Speaker 2: You must hate our troops.
explanations: Also sometimes referred to as a “false dichotomy,” this is a fallacy in which one incorrectly places limitations on one’s possible options in a given scenario. This fallacy rests on the false premise that one is faced with a binary choice when it’s possible that multiple options are available. In essence, this occurs when one reduces the array of available options and alternatives to a simplified either-or condition.

source_article: You can either support our police or Black Lives Matter.
explanations: Also sometimes referred to as a “false dichotomy,” this is a fallacy in which one incorrectly places limitations on one’s possible options in a given scenario. This fallacy rests on the false premise that one is faced with a binary choice when it’s possible that multiple options are available. In essence, this occurs when one reduces the array of available options and alternatives to a simplified either-or condition.

source_article:
Speaker 1: Did you torture the prisoner?
Speaker 2: No, we just held him under water for a while, and then did a mock hanging.
explanations: Sometimes called the Motte-and-Bailey fallacy, this is a logical fallacy in which a speaker blurs the line between two distinct positions which have some overlapping qualities. By blurring this line, it becomes possible to create an association between one position which is modest (Motte), and therefore easily defended, and a position which is likely to be more extreme (Bailey), and which is therefore more difficult to defend. By equating these positions, the speaker is presenting a false equivalence, thus forcing the other speaker to move to the defense of a position which is more difficult to defend.

source_article: According to the Supreme Court, we have a right to abortion. Therefore, it is right to have an abortion.
explanations: Legal right v. morally correct

source_article:
Speaker 1: We are using thousands of people, who are going door to door to help us spread the word about social injustice and the need for change.
Speaker: Well then, I can’t be a part of this because I was always been taught that it’s wrong to use people.
explanations: A slight variation on equivocation occurs when common terms are used in an argument but with different meanings.

source_article: What I object to most about those people who oppose capital punishment is that they believe that the lives of convicted murderers are more important than the lives of the police and prison guards who protect us. But, obviously, since the lives of those who protect us are of the greatest value, no one should oppose capital punishment.
explanations: The opponent's view is that capital punishment is wrong. This view is then misrepresented as being the view that the lives of convicted murderers are more important than the lives of the police and prison guards. The remaining two elements of the fallacy are explicitly stated in the example.

source_article: "Advocates of legalized abortion predicted it would solve our social problems. Instead, this destruction of one-fourth of a generation has left a more violent society in its wake: Child abuse has exploded, from 167,000 estimated cases in 1973 to 2.4 million in 1989, according to the National Center of Child Abuse and Neglect - a 1,400% increase. Teen suicide, among non-aborted and thus presumably "wanted" children, has doubled. Violent crime has more than doubled."
explanations: The first sentence is a straw man. Did advocates of legalized abortion ever claim it would solve problems of violent crime, etc.? Insofar as the passage suggests that abortion is the cause of these various social problems, we have a false cause fallacy.

source_article: “Feminists want to ban all pornography and punish everyone who looks at it! But such harsh measures are surely inappropriate, so the feminists are wrong: porn and its fans should be left in peace.”
explanations: The feminist argument is made weak by being overstated. In fact, most feminists do not propose an outright “ban” on porn or any punishment for those who merely view it or approve of it; often, they propose some restrictions on particular things like child porn, or propose to allow people who are hurt by porn to sue publishers and producers—not viewers—for damages. So the arguer hasn’t really scored any points; he or she has just committed a fallacy.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I think we should lower the age of sexual consent to 16.
Speaker 2: 16 year olds are children. So, you think it’s OK for children to have sex? No, we shouldn’t lower the age of consent.
explanations: The strawman fallacy occurs when a speaker appears to refute the argument of another speaker by replacing that argument with a similar but far flimsier premise. In essence, the speaker is “setting up a straw man” which can then be easily knocked down by a counterargument. The flaw in this rhetorical approach is that it fails to actually engage the original argument, in essence changing the subject so as to face a more manageable argument.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I think we should have single payer, universal, health care.
Speaker 2: Communist countries tried that. We don’t want America to be a communist country. We shouldn’t have single payer health care.
explanations: The strawman fallacy occurs when a speaker appears to refute the argument of another speaker by replacing that argument with a similar but far flimsier premise. In essence, the speaker is “setting up a straw man” which can then be easily knocked down by a counterargument. The flaw in this rhetorical approach is that it fails to actually engage the original argument, in essence changing the subject so as to face a more manageable argument.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I think we should have an expanded social safety net for the poor in our country.
Speaker 2: So, you think we should just throw money at lazy people who don’t want to work and think they are entitled to be kept up by other people, right?
explanations: The strawman fallacy occurs when a speaker appears to refute the argument of another speaker by replacing that argument with a similar but far flimsier premise. In essence, the speaker is “setting up a straw man” which can then be easily knocked down by a counterargument. The flaw in this rhetorical approach is that it fails to actually engage the original argument, in essence changing the subject so as to face a more manageable argument.

source_article: “Grading this exam on a curve would be the most fair thing to do. After all, classes go more smoothly when the students and the professor are getting along well.”
explanations:
Let’s try our premise-conclusion outlining to see what’s wrong with this argument:

Premise: Classes go more smoothly when the students and the professor are getting along well.

Conclusion: Grading this exam on a curve would be the most fair thing to do.

When we lay it out this way, it’s pretty obvious that the arguer went off on a tangent—the fact that something helps people get along doesn’t necessarily make it more fair; fairness and justice sometimes require us to do things that cause conflict. But the audience may feel like the issue of teachers and students agreeing is important and be distracted from the fact that the arguer has not given any evidence as to why a curve would be fair.

source_article:
Child: This fish tastes funny. I don’t want to eat this.
Parent: There are children starving in Africa. Eat your dinner.
explanations: The red herring fallacy refers to an instance in which one speaker attempts to divert the attention of another speaker from the primary argument by offering a point which may be true, but which does not actually further the substance of a counterargument. So named for the implication that the odoriferous fish in question might “throw one off the scent” of the actual argument itself, the red herring will typically support a conclusion with a fact which does not actually provide substantive support.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I think it’s terrible that a game hunter killed Cecil the lion.
Speaker 2: What about all the babies that are killed every day by abortion?
explanations: The red herring fallacy refers to an instance in which one speaker attempts to divert the attention of another speaker from the primary argument by offering a point which may be true, but which does not actually further the substance of a counterargument. So named for the implication that the odoriferous fish in question might “throw one off the scent” of the actual argument itself, the red herring will typically support a conclusion with a fact which does not actually provide substantive support.

source_article:
Speaker 1: I really think we need to do something about the rising levels of poverty and homelessness in our country.
Speaker 2: Why are you worried about poverty? Look how many children we abort every day.
explanations: The red herring fallacy refers to an instance in which one speaker attempts to divert the attention of another speaker from the primary argument by offering a point which may be true, but which does not actually further the substance of a counterargument. So named for the implication that the odoriferous fish in question might “throw one off the scent” of the actual argument itself, the red herring will typically support a conclusion with a fact which does not actually provide substantive support.

source_article: “We should abolish the death penalty. Many respected people, such as actor Guy Handsome, have publicly stated their opposition to it.”
explanations: While Guy Handsome may be an authority on matters having to do with acting, there’s no particular reason why anyone should be moved by his political opinions—he is probably no more of an authority on the death penalty than the person writing the paper.

source_article: Professor X holds that the use of non-invasive ventilation has no place in the management of ARDS; this, therefore, is the approach we should adopt.
explanations: Any reasonable scientist should accept a conclusion when it is sufficiently supported by evidence. The appeal to authority fallacy, however, leads to the opposite result; that is, considering a proposition to be true simply on the grounds of its being endorsed by an authority. One should always bear in mind that even authorities may be misled.

source_article: My philosophy professor believes in ghosts and goes to séances. She’s an intelligent, educated, person, so ghosts must be real, and spiritualism must be true.
explanations: The argumentum ad verecundiam, sometimes also called an “argument from authority,” describes an argument in which a speaker claims that their view is endorsed by a relevant authority figure. This claim of endorsement is presented as a sufficient argument unto itself, relieving the speaker of presenting any additional evidence to further their case. An alternate form of this fallacy is sometimes called the appeal to false or unqualified authority. In this case, the speaker might cite an individual with some measure of clout, but generally in an area outside the subject of the given argument. For instance, one might fallaciously cite a medical doctor’s opinion about politics simply because she is a very smart doctor.

source_article: My minister says the Covid vaccine will cause genetic mutations. He has a college degree, and is a holy man, so he must be right.
explanations: The argumentum ad verecundiam, sometimes also called an “argument from authority,” describes an argument in which a speaker claims that their view is endorsed by a relevant authority figure. This claim of endorsement is presented as a sufficient argument unto itself, relieving the speaker of presenting any additional evidence to further their case. An alternate form of this fallacy is sometimes called the appeal to false or unqualified authority. In this case, the speaker might cite an individual with some measure of clout, but generally in an area outside the subject of the given argument. For instance, one might fallaciously cite a medical doctor’s opinion about politics simply because she is a very smart doctor.

source_article: Aristotle thought women were inferior to men. Aristotle is one of the smartest men who ever lived, so he must be right about this.
explanations: The argumentum ad verecundiam, sometimes also called an “argument from authority,” describes an argument in which a speaker claims that their view is endorsed by a relevant authority figure. This claim of endorsement is presented as a sufficient argument unto itself, relieving the speaker of presenting any additional evidence to further their case. An alternate form of this fallacy is sometimes called the appeal to false or unqualified authority. In this case, the speaker might cite an individual with some measure of clout, but generally in an area outside the subject of the given argument. For instance, one might fallaciously cite a medical doctor’s opinion about politics simply because she is a very smart doctor.

source_article: I have no intention of stopping the use of somatostatin on patients suffering from acute pancreatitis. I consider it to be a very reasonable choice. After all, it has been standard practice in our department for many years and we’ve been quite satisfied with the results we’ve had.
explanations: The fallacy illustrated above contains two errors. On the one hand it presumes that the “traditional” premise is correctly established, having been adequately supported by evidence since it was first accepted – without considering the possibility of methodological errors or inaccuracies. On the other, it considers that the conditions justifying the adoption of the “traditional” proposition are eternal and unchanging, an assumption that could very well be wrong.

source_article: To my knowledge, there are no studies supporting this approach. Therefore, I see no reason to change our routine.
explanations: In science, the validity of a proposition should be based on the positive evidence presented, not on the absence of facts that disprove it. A very useful quote by Carl Sagan comes to mind here: “Absence of evidence is not evidence of absence”

source_article: No one has proven God exists, so He doesn’t.
explanations: Argumentum ad ignorantiam, also sometimes referred to as an “argument from ignorance,” occurs when a speaker presents an argument as fact simply because there is no readily available evidence to prove the contrary. This fallacy is based on a false dichotomy which posits that what we don’t know must not be true. This strategy incorrectly assumes that a lack of sufficient evidence is concrete proof that something can’t be true, a position which precludes the possibility that things may be unknown or even unknowable.

source_article: We haven’t proven aliens didn’t create life on earth, so aliens created life on earth.
explanations: Argumentum ad ignorantiam, also sometimes referred to as an “argument from ignorance,” occurs when a speaker presents an argument as fact simply because there is no readily available evidence to prove the contrary. This fallacy is based on a false dichotomy which posits that what we don’t know must not be true. This strategy incorrectly assumes that a lack of sufficient evidence is concrete proof that something can’t be true, a position which precludes the possibility that things may be unknown or even unknowable.

source_article: We haven’t found the ruins of Troy, so the city of Troy didn’t really exist.
explanations: Argumentum ad ignorantiam, also sometimes referred to as an “argument from ignorance,” occurs when a speaker presents an argument as fact simply because there is no readily available evidence to prove the contrary. This fallacy is based on a false dichotomy which posits that what we don’t know must not be true. This strategy incorrectly assumes that a lack of sufficient evidence is concrete proof that something can’t be true, a position which precludes the possibility that things may be unknown or even unknowable.

source_article: We haven’t found King David’s tomb, so King David didn’t really exist.
explanations: Argumentum ad ignorantiam, also sometimes referred to as an “argument from ignorance,” occurs when a speaker presents an argument as fact simply because there is no readily available evidence to prove the contrary. This fallacy is based on a false dichotomy which posits that what we don’t know must not be true. This strategy incorrectly assumes that a lack of sufficient evidence is concrete proof that something can’t be true, a position which precludes the possibility that things may be unknown or even unknowable.

source_article: Have you stopped beating your wife?
explanations: A loaded question is one in which the speaker has employed rhetorical manipulation in order to limit the possible array of answers that another speaker can rationally provide. The fallacy is couched in the phrasing of such a question, which presupposes certain facts that may not be true or proven, within the content of the question. The fallacy occurs when that question is underscored by a presupposition which is not agreed upon by the person to whom the question is posed.
rationale: Added intentional fallacy based on fallacy list.

source_article: Why did you steal my keys?
explanations: A loaded question is one in which the speaker has employed rhetorical manipulation in order to limit the possible array of answers that another speaker can rationally provide. The fallacy is couched in the phrasing of such a question, which presupposes certain facts that may not be true or proven, within the content of the question. The fallacy occurs when that question is underscored by a presupposition which is not agreed upon by the person to whom the question is posed.
rationale: Added intentional fallacy based on fallacy list.

source_article: Are you one of those stupid religious people that reject science?
explanations: A loaded question is one in which the speaker has employed rhetorical manipulation in order to limit the possible array of answers that another speaker can rationally provide. The fallacy is couched in the phrasing of such a question, which presupposes certain facts that may not be true or proven, within the content of the question. The fallacy occurs when that question is underscored by a presupposition which is not agreed upon by the person to whom the question is posed.
rationale: Added intentional fallacy based on fallacy list.

source_article: My friend swears the mechanic at that shop overcharged her last week and after looking at her invoice it seems she’s right. So don’t take your business there, as you’ll definitely get ripped off.
explanations: Supports a universal claim on the basis of a single example

source_article: All Greek food causes illness;  when I traveled through Greece, I got food  poisoning.
explanations: The writer makes a rule out of particular experiences to support the claim.  As soon as an exception to the derived rule is found, the rule fails to support the argument.

source_article: All engineers are introverts who would rather relate to computers than people.
explanations: Draws a conclusion about a large group based on the experiences of a few members of the group.
rationale: Clearly there are many engineers who are outgoing and football players who are very intelligent. It is very dangerous to make sweeping generalizations regarding a group based on limited experience.

source_article: All football players are dumb jocks.
rationale: Clearly there are many engineers who are outgoing and football players who are very intelligent. It is very dangerous to make sweeping generalizations regarding a group based on limited experience.

source_article: People nowadays only vote with their emotions instead of their brains.
explanations: A hasty generalization is a claim based on a few examples rather than substantial proof. Arguments based on hasty generalizations often don't hold up due to a lack of supporting evidence: The claim might be true in one case, but that doesn't mean it's always true.

source_article: Gas prices have been rising steadily these past few years. Thus, the cost of car ownership is higher than it was previously.
explanations: you cannot assume that just because you know something about a component or entity within a group that the same information will apply to the group as a whole (or to the entire entity being considered).

source_article: The United States is the wealthiest nation in the world. So every American is wealthy.
explanations: Presumes, without providing justification, that what is true of a whole must also be true of its constituent parts

source_article: If you miss practice, it means you were probably goofing off. People who goof off drop out of school and end up penniless.
explanations: The slippery slope fallacy takes a benign premise or starting point and suggests that it will lead to unlikely or ridiculous outcomes with no supporting evidence.

source_article: But you have to let me go to the party! If I don't go to the party, I'll be a loser with no friends. Next thing you know, I'll end up alone and jobless, living in your basement when I'm 30!
explanations: A slippery slope argument assumes that a certain course of action will necessarily lead to a chain of future events.

source_article: The anti-terrorist laws that monitor international currency transfers, phone calls, and emails are the first step to turning our fragile democracy into a new Nazi regime.
explanations: This argument assumes that if one bad thing happens, then another much worse thing will necessarily happen.
rationale: Although infringements of civil liberties are troublesome, it is another argument to suggest infringements of civil liberties will lead to a fascist dictatorship.

source_article:
John: We should oppose any attempt to register firearms. Such regulation is the first step to confiscation of all weapons and the elimination of our constitutional right to bear arms.

Ted: This is preposterous. Many things in society are registered, such as cars, babies, boats, and lanes, yet these items have never been confiscated.
rationale:
Ted is making a faulty analogy between registration of guns and registration of cars and babies. But guns are frequently used as instruments of intentional violence and therefore may be more likely targets for confiscation.

John is making a slippery slope argument that registration of firearms must invariably lead to the elimination of a constitutional right.

source_article: If we put limits on the right to bear arms, soon all of our Constitutionally-given  rights will be taken away.
explanations: The writer bases the claim on the assumption that if a particular event occurs, so will other undesirable events.  However, there are no reasons to believe that the subsequent events will occur.  This fallacy is usually caused by fear.

source_article: A father talking to his daughter on dating a boyfriend he doesn’t like says, “If you continue dating this guy who doesn’t take his education seriously, you’ll end up dropping out of school, you then won’t be able to get a job, and you will get married too young.”
explanations: Assumes that if this fact is true then everything else follows.
rationale: Dating someone who doesn’t take education seriously does not mean the daughter will drop out of school herself, marry early, and be unemployable.

source_article: Since many of the students at St. Cloud State University get A's, St. Cloud State must  be a top-rated school.
explanations: The writer makes a claim based on the belief that a whole always possesses the characteristics of its parts, which is often untrue.  Although this belief is sometimes acceptable, it is not universally applicable, so the appropriateness of using this idea must be determined on a case by case basis.

source_article: IBM is a reputable organization, so all of its employees must be reputable.
explanations: The writer erroneously assumes that because a whole has a particular property, the parts forming the whole have the same property.

source_article: At a party you overhear a friend tell her spouse, “I had high blood pressure at the doctor’s office today; I really need to reduce the stress in my job.”
explanations: Explains an event by attributing it to a single factor, when many factors are involved or by overemphasizing the importance of a single factor.
rationale: This friend is obviously attributing the high blood pressure reading to job-related stress, while there may be many additional contributing or more important factors (lack of exercise, poor diet, genetic predisposition, white-coat syndrome, etc.).

source_article: Duke University has the best basketball player in the NCAA, therefore they will win the tournament this year.
explanations: This is assuming that one part of something has to be applied to all, or other, parts of it.

source_article: Running the government is like running a business. You can’t keep running into debt and expect to be successful.
explanations: The author argues that two things are similar in some ways, therefore they are similar in all ways.
rationale: Think about where the two things are not similar. Isn’t the goal of government quite different than the goal of business?

source_article: Ten years ago I got a 170 on the LSAT, so I expect to get the same score again.
explanations: This fallacy is committed when it is assumed, without justification, that background conditions have remained the same at different times/locations. In most instances, this is an unwarranted assumption for the simple reason that things rarely remain the same over extended periods of time, and things rarely remain the same from place to place.

source_article: The last Democrat winner of the New Hampshire primary won the general election. This year, the winner of the New Hampshire primary will win the general election.
rationale: The assumption operative in this argument is that nothing has changed since the last primary. No evidence or justification is offered for this assumption.

source_article: The more things change, the more they remain the same.
Having a television rating system is like being in prison.  Both infringe on one's rights.
explanations: The writer reasons by analogy, using a similar, known situation as the basis for the argument.  Extended analogies tend to lose their direct connection with the actual topic of discussion, leading to erroneous conclusions.

source_article: A year is 365 days long, so I celebrate my birthday every 365 days.
explanations: The writer applies a general rule to a case where the rule is inapplicable.

source_article: Every time that rooster crows, the sun comes up. That rooster must be very powerful and important!

I believe in supernatural beings because every time I drive past the cemetery where  my grandmother is buried, a light on my dashboard flashes.  Her spirit causes this because it never happens otherwise.
explanations: The writer assumes that because two events occur consecutively or concurrently, they are causally related.

source_article: Jimmy isn't at school today. He must be on a family trip.
explanations: One example is the false cause fallacy, which is when you draw a conclusion about what the cause was without enough evidence to do so.

source_article: Bush was "determined to knock down Saddam Hussein" because of his "nuclear  bomb potential."
explanations: The writer points out as the cause of an event something that is not the actual cause, or the writer has insufficient evidence for making a causal link.  If the identified cause is not the real cause, nothing assures that the point of discussion is true.

source_article: I must be telling the truth, since I’m not lying.
explanations: How would you know I’m telling the truth? Well, according to me in this example, it’s because I say I’m not lying. But you would have no more reason to believe that premise (not lying) than you would to believe the conclusion (telling the truth), and vice versa.
rationale: If you spot an argument where the conclusion is synonymous with one of the premises, and no evidence has been given to show that the premise is correct/true, you’ve got a circular argument. At that point you can quickly scan the answers for one that describes the author presuming to be true the thing he/she is attempting to prove.

source_article: Everything I say is true. This is true because I said it, and everything I say is true.
explanations: The premise is a mere restatement of the conclusion.

source_article: God exists because the Bible says so. The Bible is a reliable source because it is the  word of God.
explanations: The writer defends the claim by using the conclusion as one of the premises to support the conclusion.

source_article: Smoking pot is against the law because it's wrong; I know it's wrong because it is against the law.
explanations: Circular arguments occur when a person's argument repeats what they already assumed before without arriving at a new conclusion.

source_article: According to my brain, my brain is reliable.
explanations: Circular arguments often use a claim as both a premise and a conclusion. This fallacy only appears to be an argument when in fact it's just restating one's assumptions.

source_article: Everyone knows that Japanese DVD players are the best. After all, the outsell American players two-to-one.
explanations: Something must be true, since many people (or a certain group of people) believe it to be true.
rationale: Just because a lot of people believe something doesn’t make it right. Could it be that there are twice as many Japanese manufacturers of DVD players?

source_article: Millions of people are Marxists, so Marxist economic and political theories are  correct.
explanations: The writer bases the argument on the belief that if an idea is held by a large group of people, it is true.

source_article: An opinion article in a campus newspaper states that in an all-campus survey 95% of students think that tuition should be lowered and therefore tuition should be lowered immediately.
Almost everyone at my school will be at the party Friday night. It must be the right thing to do.
explanations: The bandwagon fallacy assumes something is true (or right or good) because others agree with it. In other words, the fallacy argues that if everyone thinks a certain way, then you should, too.

source_article: Everyone knows that Japanese DVD players are the best. After all, the outsell American players two-to-one.
explanations: Something must be true, since many people (or a certain group of people) believe it to be true.
rationale: Just because a lot of people believe something doesn’t make it right. Could it be that there are twice as many Japanese manufacturers of DVD players?

source_article: Discoveries from Archimedes should be dismissed because he made them in a bathtub and not a proper university laboratory.
explanations: This is a fallacy where you dismiss something based on where it came from.

source_article: Boris is not qualified to make suggestions about our penal system. As an ex-convict, he would always take the criminals’ side.
explanations: The author attacks the supporter of another argument, instead of the argument itself.
rationale: Separate the attack on a person from the reasoning. Couldn’t it be just as true that Boris is more qualified to make suggestions than most, given that he’s seen the other side of the penal system?

source_article: Mayor Jones’ anti-DUI campaign should not be taken seriously. After all, the mayor himself was cited for driving under the influence in college
explanations: Also known as an ad hominem attack (meaning “to the person”), a Source Argument commits a singular, consistent mistake by attacking the person/group making a claim (the source), as opposed to attacking the details of the claim itself.
rationale: assuming that a claim is false on the grounds that the person defending it is of questionable character

source_article: She asserts that we need more military spending, but that is false, since she is only saying it because she is a Republican.
explanations: A Circumstantial ad Hominem is a fallacy in which one attempts to attack a claim by asserting that the person making the claim is making it simply out of self interest.

source_article: I think that we should reject what Father Jones has to say about the ethical issues of abortion because he is a Catholic priest. After all, Father Jones is required to hold such views
Of course the Senator from Maine opposes a reduction in naval spending. After all, Bath Ironworks, which produces warships, is in Maine.
Bill claims that tax breaks for corporations increases development. Of course, Bill is the CEO of a corporation.
Oprah Winfrey's diet advice is useless;  she has had problems with maintaining her weight for most of her life, bouncing back and forth between being overweight and slender.
explanations: The writer reduces the credibility of the opposition by attacking them personally for who they are and not for what they say.  The validity of logical reasoning does not depend on the morality of the speaker.

source_article: MacDougal roots for a British football team. Clearly he's unfit to be a police chief in Ireland.
explanations: This fallacy occurs when someone rejects or criticizes another point of view based on the personal characteristics, ethnic background, physical appearance, or other non-relevant traits of the person who holds it.

source_article: But, Dad, I know you smoked when you were my age, so how can you tell me not to do it?
explanations: The tu quoque fallacy is an attempt to divert blame. The fallacy usually occurs when the arguer uses apparent hypocrisy to neutralize criticism and distract from the issue.

source_article: The house is white; therefore it must be big
explanations: This means “does not follow,” which indicates that the conclusion does not follow from the premise.
rationale: Just because a house is white doesn’t mean that the house must be big.

source_article: If one is 16 years old or older, one can drive an automobile in Wisconsin.  I saw  your niece driving through Wausau yesterday.  She must be at least 16.
explanations: The writer uses an If...then statement in the argument's reasoning.  Then, the writer confirms the then part of the statement and derives the If part, thereby committing a serious logical flaw.

source_article: Mayor: During my previous term as mayor my staff and I spent a great deal of time focusing on our city’s economy, and unemployment reached an all-time high as a result. So clearly you should support my re-election campaign if you are among those still looking for a job.
explanations: This particular mistake, also sometimes called a “self-contradiction,” occurs when an author’s conclusion is actually opposite the conclusion that is best supported by the given premises.
rationale: introduces information that actually contradicts the conclusion

source_article: All judges are fair-minded individuals;  therefore, Judge Ito is fair in his decisions.
explanations: The writer's reasons for holding a belief are not as obvious to the audience as they are to the writer, and the writer does not back up the claim with enough support.  This fallacy also occurs when the writer introduces an unsupported value judgment.

source_article: If the ozone layer is destroyed, many people will get cancer and suffer from other illnesses.  The ozone layer is being protected, not destroyed.  So, many people will be spared the pain of cancer and other illnesses.
explanations: Again, the writer employs an If...then statement, but in this case, the writer denies the If part so that the negation of the then part can be concluded.  However, just because the If part does not happen, it does not follow that the then part will not happen.  The then part could result for some other reason.

source_article: You have to give me a passing grade. I spent 150 hours on that project and missed every party this quarter.
explanations: The author plays on your emotions to get you to agree with the conclusion.

source_article: Professor, please, PLEASE reconsider my grade on the Final! I know I only answered 7% of the questions correctly, but I didn’t really deserve an F! In the past week I sprained my ankle, my dog ran away, and my kitchen caught on fire! I think it’s only fair I get a chance to retake the test!
explanations: n this type of error a speaker will use emotion or emotionally-charged language to attempt to persuade a reader/listener that a particular position or belief is correct, when the emotion described gives no tangible reasons (only emotional or ethically-based ones) to accept a conclusion.
rationale: the argument appeals to emotion rather than to reason

source_article: I cannot get a job because the public education system failed me;  I have to steal to  survive.  It is society's fault, not mine.
explanations: The writer begs for the approval of the claim;  the audience may agree because they feel sorry for the arguer.

source_article: Professor, you have to give me an A on this paper. I know I only turned in a sentence and some clip art, but you have to understand, my grandmother suddenly died while traveling in the Northern Yukon, and her funeral was there so I had to travel, and my parents got divorced in the middle of the ceremony, and all the stress caused me to become catatonic for two weeks. Have some pity — my grandmother's last wish was that I'd get an A in this class.
explanations: An appeal to pity relies on provoking your emotions to win an argument rather than factual evidence.

source_article: Same-sex marriage must be prohibited, or the family structure as we know it will  collapse.
explanations: The writer uses emotive language that will produce a desired effect on a group or "gallery" of readers.  By appealing to the fears or interests of the audience, the writer hopes to gain approval.

source_article: Evolution cannot be true. If it were true, we’d all be smelly apes.
explanations: Notice how the consequences are unrelated to the argument. Regardless of how you feel about evolution, if it is true, aren’t we all still human?

source_article: If you don’t agree to sign the labor agreement, we’ll fire you.
explanations: The author practically threatens anyone who disagrees with her conclusion.
rationale: If an author makes any kind of threat, is the threat related at all to the conclusion? What does getting fired have to do with believing that an agreement is correct?

source_article: If you do not believe in God, you will go to hell.
explanations: The writer threatens the audience, explicitly or implicitly, with negative consequences if the claim is not believed.

source_article: Because recent polling indicates that no voters in the county are strongly in favor of the proposed amendment, we can expect strong opposition to the amendment when it is voted on next month.
explanations: A False Dilemma argument assumes that only two possible courses of action (or two possible choices) are available, when in fact there may be others.
rationale: fails to consider that some voters may be neither strong supporters nor strong opponents of the suggested amendment.

source_article: In the United States, one can vote for either Democrats or Republicans.
explanations: The writer only presents some of the alternatives for solving a problem when more possibilities exist because the writer assumes that the list of alternatives created is exhaustive.

source_article: At a recent cocktail party, the conversation has turned to family pets, and your friend asks you “Are you a cat or a dog person?"
explanations: Assumes the choices stated by the author are the only ones that exist, or generally constrains the scope of a discussion to force a point.
rationale: Your choices here have clearly been limited to two, when in reality there are many others: you may have no interest in pets at all, you may be a bird person, or you may enjoy cats and dogs equally.

source_article: Either we go to war or we appear weak.
explanations: A false dilemma or false dichotomy presents limited options — typically by focusing on two extremes — when in fact more possibilities exist

source_article: Either you love me or you hate me.
explanations: The false dilemma fallacy is a manipulative tool designed to polarize the audience, promoting one side and demonizing another.

source_article: America: Love it or leave it
explanations: It's common in political discourse as a way of strong-arming the public into supporting controversial legislation or policies.

source_article: Either you are with me or you are against me.
explanations: The argument above assumes that there are only two possible alternatives open to us. There is no room for a middle ground.

source_article: Either you believe what I’m saying, or you must believe exactly the opposite.
explanations: The argument above assumes that there are only two possible alternatives open to us. There is no room for a middle ground.

source_article: In the United States, one can vote for either Democrats or Republicans.
explanations: The writer only presents some of the alternatives for solving a problem when more possibilities exist because the writer assumes that the list of alternatives created is exhaustive.

source_article: Don’t waste your money on a home security system; master thieves will still be able to get into your house.
explanations: Assumes that if a part of the problem is not satisfied or solved (even a small part), then the entire solution should be abandoned.
rationale: However, many thieves may be deterred by a security system

source_article: I like my steak rare. But I don’t care for aardvark steak, even though it’s the rarest steak in the world.
explanations: The argument switches between two definitions of the same word.
rationale: Uses the same word multiple times but in different contexts.

source_article: It is immoral to kill an innocent human being.  Fetuses are innocent human  beings.  Therefore, it is immoral to kill fetuses.
explanations: The writer uses two different senses of the same word in an argument, and this ambiguity allows a mistaken conclusion to be drawn by the writer.
rationale: In the first sentence, the writer uses "human being" in the sense of a  morally considerable being.  In the second, the writer could be using the term  "human being" to make the less controversial claim that a fetus is a genetically  human creature.

source_article: “Every society is, of course, repressive to some extent – as Sigmund Freud pointed out, repression is the price we pay for civilization.”
explanations: The Fallacy of Equivocation occurs when a word or phrase that has more than one meaning is employed with different meanings throughout the argument
rationale: In this example, the word “repression” is used in two completely different contexts. “Repression” in Freud’s mind meant restricting sexual and psychological desires. “Repression” in the second context does not mean repression of individual desires but government restriction of individual liberties, such as that in a totalitarian state.

source_article: He said a lovely lady like me doesn't have to worry about his bear because this is a man-eating bear.
rationale: man means homo sapiens, not male gender

source_article: His political party wants to spend your precious tax dollars on big government. But my political party is planning strategic federal investment in critical programs.
explanations: Equivocation happens when a word, phrase, or sentence is used deliberately to confuse, deceive, or mislead. In other words, saying one thing but meaning another.

source_article: I don't understand why you're saying I broke a promise. I said I'd never speak to my ex-girlfriend again. And I didn't. I just sent her some pictures and text messages.

old_label: uncertain use of term or concept
source_article:
Board Member: “If this company is going to maximize its profits in the coming year, we need to fully exploit all of our available resources.”
Human Resources Director: “Not so fast. Our employees are one of our most valued resources, and we have a strict policy against exploiting our workers.”
explanations: This particular mistake violates an argumentative principle to which authors must adhere—as an argument progresses, each term and concept discussed must be used in a consistent, coherent fashion.
rationale: it confuses two different meanings of the word ‘exploit’

old_label: uncertain use of term or concept
source_article:
Board Member: “If this company is going to maximize its profits in the coming year, we need to fully exploit all of our available resources.”
Human Resources Director: “Not so fast. Our employees are one of our most valued resources, and we have a strict policy against exploiting our workers.”
explanations: This particular mistake violates an argumentative principle to which authors must adhere—as an argument progresses, each term and concept discussed must be used in a consistent, coherent fashion.
rationale: it confuses two different meanings of the word ‘exploit’

source_article: Al Gore's support of the discussion of sexual orientation issues on Ellen is  dangerous:  he advocates the exposure of children to sexually explicit materials,  which is wrong.
explanations: The writer does not attack the argument that the opposition sets forth.  The arguer may attack one of the opposition's points as if it were the whole argument, distort what the opposition is attempting to express, or exaggerate the opposition's argument to the point of satirizing it.

source_article: Recent auto accidents in your neighborhood have led you to propose to the city council that the speed limit along Main Street be reduced to calm the traffic flow. Opponents complain that reducing speed limits all over town is counterproductive and an unnecessary burden on drivers.
explanations: Discredits an exaggerated version of an argument.
rationale: The straw person argument here is the expansion of your proposal from “a lower speed limit on one street” to “speed limits all over town.” The acknowledgment of this new alternative argument deflects the focus from your true proposal.

source_article: The Senator thinks we can solve all our ecological problems by driving a Prius.
explanations: A straw man argument attacks a different subject rather than the topic being discussed — often a more extreme version of the counter argument.

source_article: Quite the contrary: The Senator thinks the environment is such a wreck that no one's car choice or driving habits would make the slightest difference.
We must eliminate affirmative action. We can’t rely on laws to end racial prejudice.
explanations: The author attacks a different argument than the one under consideration.

source_article: You call your cell phone provider to complain about how poor your cell phone battery life is after the recent software update. The representative, instead of responding to your concern, praises the provider’s new unlimited text-messaging plans that are due to be released in the next month.
explanations: Introduces an irrelevant topic to distract the conversation from the main point.
rationale: Your phone’s battery life will not be improved by being able to send more text messages.

source_article: My roommate wants to talk about cleaning out the garage, so I asked her what she wants to do with our patio furniture. Now she's shopping for new patio furniture and not asking me about the garage.
explanations: A red herring is an argument that uses confusion or distraction to shift attention away from a topic and toward a false conclusion. Red herrings usually contain an unimportant fact, idea, or event that has little relevance to the real issue.

source_article: Education is important for the future of the American people and our country.   So, you should choose to study at St. Cloud State University.
explanations: The writer introduces irrelevant material to distract the audience from the subject at hand.  Then, s/he draws conclusions based on the unrelated material presented.

source_article: People have believed that fish is "brain food" for decades, so I don't believe the  FDA when they claim that eating fish does not enhance the intellect.
explanations: The writer relies on traditional wisdom to support the argument.  This is a logical pitfall because the argument does not consider that new ideas could apply.

source_article: World-renowned physicist Dr. Patricia Mitchell assures me that exposure to natural sunlight, even exposure resulting in mild sunburn, is still significantly less of a cancer risk than brief exposure to the artificial light in a tanning bed. So I make sure to tell all of my friends that if they’re looking to get a tan this summer they should do it outdoors, and not at the tanning salon!
explanations: This could just as easily be titled, “Appeal to Improper Authority,” as this error occurs when an argument is based on evidence provided by someone who could be considered a person of authority/expertise on a subject, or in a field, that is not necessarily related to the subject in the conclusion.
rationale: the judgment of experts is applied to a matter in which their expertise is not relevant

source_article: I think that businesses should not have to limit the amount of pollutants they  release into the atmosphere because Rush Limbaugh says that there is no real  evidence for industrial pollutants causing the Greenhouse Effect.
explanations: The writer cites authorities to show the validity of the claim, but the authority is not an expert in the field, the authority's view is taken out of context, or other experts of that field disagree with the authority quoted.

source_article: Ignore any scientific ideas from anyone who didn’t get a Ph.D.
explanations: This is using the opinion or position of an authority figure, or institution of authority, as a trump card over an actual argument.

source_article: Because Martin Sheen played the president on television, he'd probably make a great president in real life.
explanations: Appeal to authority is the misuse of an authority's opinion to support an argument. While an authority's opinion can represent evidence and data, it becomes a fallacy if their expertise or authority is overstated, illegitimate, or irrelevant to the topic.

source_article: One day robots will enslave us all. It's true. My computer science teacher says so.
John agrees with me that drinking energy drinks are bad for you.
explanations: Gives credibility to someone who has no expertise in the area.
rationale: What makes John an expert on the perils of drinking energy drinks? John could be an expert dietician studying the subject or he may have no basis for knowing anything about the effects of energy drinks on the body other than an uneducated opinion.

source_article: Word processed papers are clearer and more error-free than typed papers  because they make use of new technology.
explanations: The writer claims that a new discovery has better effects or is more applicable to a given situation simply because it is new.  However, being newer does not make an idea more correct.

source_article: I believe in God because no one can prove that a god doesn't exist.
explanations: The writer's argument is simply that the point has not been proven otherwise.  The fact that the counterclaim has not been proven does not make a claim correct.

source_article: The ideas from that member of the club are wrong, but he isn’t actually a true member of the club so his ideas do not matter.
explanations: This is a “purity test” where you rebut an argument by saying that the offender really wasn’t a member of your group.

source_article:
Person 1: If you are a Marvel fan then you love Avengers: Endgame.
Person 2: I am a Marvel fan and I did not love Avengers: Endgame.
Person 1: Well you aren’t a TRUE Marvel fan.”
explanations: This is a “purity test” where you rebut an argument by saying that the offender really wasn’t a member of your group.

source_article: Everyone should be patient and wait for his or her turn in line. However, I need to go to the front because I am late for an appointment.
explanations: This is moving the goalposts or making up an exception when a claim is shown to be false. This is similar to shifting the burden of proof.

source_article: The Geo Metro is a superior car because it averages 43 miles per gallon.
explanations: The writer, consciously or unconsciously, establishes conclusions without stating all of the facts relevant to the situation.
rationale: The writer neglects to mention that this figure was derived in tests where the car was driven with 30 mile per hour tailwinds.

source_article: No one has ever been able to prove that extraterrestrials exist, so they must not be real.
explanations: An appeal to ignorance (also known as an "argument from ignorance") argues that a proposition must be true because it has not been proven false or there is no evidence against it.

source_article: No one has ever been able to prove that extraterrestrials do not exist, so they must be real.
We have no evidence that the Illuminati ever existed. They must have been so clever that they destroyed all the evidence.
The model is in close agreement with the data.
explanations: Uses words, phrases, or sentences that have multiple interpretations or really don’t say anything.
rationale: What does the word “close” mean? What is the measure of a “close agreement”? Within 10%? 50%?

old_label: false, incomplete, or misleading facts or statements
source_article: Because 90% of college students polled had no debt, education costs are not a problem.
explanations: Presents data in such a way that it falsely leads someone to the wrong conclusion.
rationale: It’s possible that only 10 college students were polled or the poll was taken at a banquet for scholarship students.

source_article: The author writes that animals shouldn't be killed because they can feel pain,  but  he doesn't prove that they can.  For his argument to persuade me, he has to give  me positive empirical evidence of animals' ability to feel pain.
explanations: The writer challenges those with an opposing view to defend their arguments;  this puts the writer in a position in which s/he can deny the opposition's assertions.

source_article: Who could disagree with the bipartisan plan to raise spending far over tax revenues?
explanations: This fallacy is the opposite of the either/or fallacy. Instead of the either/or extremism, the middle ground fallacy is moderation to the extreme.
rationale: The correct solution is the compromise between the two parties.

source_article: I know this relationship isn't working anymore and that we're both miserable. No marriage. No kids. No steady job. But I've been with him for seven years, so I'd better stay with him.
explanations: A sunk cost fallacy is when someone continues doing something because of the effort they already put in it, regardless of whether the additional costs outweigh the potential benefits.

source_article: 10 of the last 14 National Spelling Bee Champions have been Indian American. Indian Americans must all be great spellers!
Some teenagers in our community recently vandalized the park downtown. Teenagers are so irresponsible and destructive.
This legislation is sinful because it is the wrong thing to do.
Either we pass this ordinance or there will be rioting in the streets.
If you are not with us, you are against us.
My child was diagnosed with autism after receiving vaccinations. That is proof that vaccines are to blame.
I hear the rain falling outside my window; therefore, the sun is not shining.
My opponent says I am weak on crime, but I have been one of the most reliable participants in city council meetings.
Senator Smith says we should cut back the Defense budget. His position is that we should let down our defenses and just trust our enemies not to attack us!
Without this additional insurance, you could find yourself broke and homeless.
I know I missed assignments, but if you fail me, I will lose my financial aid and have to drop out.
We can’t legalize marijuana; if we do, then the next thing you know people will be strung out on heroin.
Everyone is getting tattoos in college, so you might as well do it too.
Of course that doctor advocates vaccination—he probably owns stock in a pharmaceutical company.
Person 1: “I am for raising the minimum wage in our state.” Person 2: “She is for raising the minimum wage, but she is not even smart enough to run a business.
Dr. X is an engineer, and he doesn’t believe in global warming.
My opponent is a card-carrying member of the K.K.K.
Because the last words spoken by either the pilot or co-pilot were "Good night, Malaysia Three-Seven-Zero," the pilot fell asleep and accidentally crashed the plane into the ocean.
A news story that reported that Captain Shah was under investigation was shared widely on social media. He must have been the individual who caused the crash.
This crash will likely damage the reputation of Malaysia Airlines, which will hurt the tourism industry of Malaysia and ruin their economy.
“The best minds in physics have studied physics most of their lives, as it’s necessary to study physics extensively to become a top physicist.”
explanations: Circular reasoning occurs when someone makes an argument in which both the premises and the conclusion have to rely on the truthfulness of the other.

source_article: “You should always do what you are being told because following the rules is important.”
explanations: Circular reasoning occurs when someone makes an argument in which both the premises and the conclusion have to rely on the truthfulness of the other.

source_article: “It’s important to argue logically because logic is an essential part of argumentation.”
explanations: Circular reasoning occurs when someone makes an argument in which both the premises and the conclusion have to rely on the truthfulness of the other.

source_article: A warm beer is better than a cold beer. After all, nothing is better than a cold beer, and a warm beer is better than nothing.
explanations: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.

source_article: Noisy children are a real headache. Two aspirin will make a headache go away. Therefore, two aspirin will make noisy children go away.
explanations: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.

source_article: I don't see how you can say you're an ethical person. It's so hard to get you to do anything; your work ethic is so bad
explanations: The fallacy of equivocation occurs when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.

source_article:
Q: Did the President have an affair?
A: "He's very busy at the moment with the Middle East Peace talks, and has no time for
 silly accusations."
explanations: (Ignoring the Question): when a rebuttal doesn't address the question

source_article: Putting teenagers in sex-education classes is like taking an alcoholic to a bar.
explanations: (Are the things being compared even similar? Does that prove anything?)

source_article:
Your mom thinks you spend too much time playing video games. You bring up that
she spends too much time shopping.
explanations:
The shopping is a red herring, since the original issue was
video games.

source_article:
Premise: All black bears are omnivores.

Premise: All raccoons are omnivores.

Conclusion: All raccoons are black bears.
explanations: Bears are a subset of omnivores. Raccoons also are a subset of omnivores. But these two subsets do not overlap, and that fact makes the conclusion illogical. The argument is invalid—that is, the relationship between the premises doesn’t support the conclusion.

source_article: "Aliens must exist because there is no evidence that they don't exist."
explanations: argues that a proposition is true because it has not yet been proven false

source_article: I've had bad luck for so long that I'm bound to have good luck now.
explanations: assumes that short-term deviations will correct themselves

source_article: My dad went to school, so he knows everything about the education system.
explanations: attaching an argument to a person of false or appeared authority in order to give credence to their argument

source_article: Lots of people bought this album, so it must be good.
explanations: claiming that an idea or belief is true simply because it is what most people believe

source_article: You're complaining because you have to walk to school? I used to have to give my parents my entire paycheck.
explanations: uses irrelevant information or other techniques to distract from the argument at hand

source_article: You let my sister pierce her ears when she was 11, so you should let me stay up until midnight.
explanations: employs analogies between things that are not really alike

source_article: My best friend says you’re a liar, so I’m not going to talk to you.
explanations: involves acceptance or rejection of concepts based on their source, not their merit
